awd_titl_txt: Bundles and Conformal Blocks with a Twist
awd_abstract_narration:
The international conference "Bundles and Conformal Blocks with a Twist" will take place June 13-17 2022 at the International Center for Mathematical Sciences in Edinburgh, Scotland. The aim of this event is to bring together a diverse group of researchers, from a mixture of fields and in different stages of their careers, to disseminate recent work, to foster collaborations, and to develop future connections. It is the first conference on the subject and this grant provides support for US-based participants. The conference website is at https://twistedcb.wixsite.com/conferenceicms. 
 
The main research foci of the conference are geometric representation theory, differential and algebraic geometry, and cohomological/topological field theory. In particular the conference will focus on three interconnected topics: (a) parahoric torsors and their moduli spaces, (b) twisted conformal blocks, their properties and relations with moduli spaces of parahoric torsors, (c) topological and cohomological field theories and their generalizations which arise from (twisted) conformal blocks. The conference will follow the usual format with research talks and an introductory lecture series that the organizers hope will be a fundamental review article for the subject.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The conference "Bundles and Conformal Blocks with a Twist" took place between June 13th and June 17th 2022. With a total of 20 speakers (of which 6 gave online talks) and 49 participants (of which 21 took part online), this conference has successfully brought together experts and young researchers in the areas of geometric representation theory, differential and algebraic geometry, and cohomological/topological field theory.  The NSF funds supported eight participants based in the US. The conference was also supported by Edinburgh Mathematical Society, by Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council, Foundation Compositio Mathematica, Glasgow Mathematical Journal Trust and by the International Centre for Mathematical Sciences (ICMS).

The balance between speakers and participants on the bundles-side and on the conformal blocks-side was very good, and led to a number of interactions that are likely to bear scientific fruit, as commented on in the feedback received.  The quality of the talks was very high, aided by a good blend of senior and junior speakers. The four hours of introductory lectures by Jochen Heinloth worked very well in making the topic of this workshop accessible to researchers of adjacent fields. As the recordings of these lectures (as well as the other talks) will become available on the ICMS media page (https://www.icms.org.uk/workshops/2022/bundles-and-conformal-blocks-twist), this will likely have a lasting impact.

Given the timing of the workshop after two years of COVID-related restrictions, there was clearly a great appetite among participants for in-person scientific interactions.  The various social events organized clearly aided this and were very well received.
